original_title: Sri Lanka to increase fuel quota in coming month: Energy Minister
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Sri Lanka is to increase fuel quotas in the coming month, as fuel cargo plans and supply have been reviewed by the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation (CPC), Minister of Energy Kanchana Wijesekara said today (20).

“Fuel import plans, refinery operations, refinery upgrade proposals, QR quotas, storage capacity, stock automaton, agreements with fuel stations, and distribution as was reviewed  and discussed.” Minister Wijesekera said in a Twitter.com message.
Consequently, fuel quotas are to be increased next month, after the evaluation.
Sri Lanka increased a fuel ration by a third to 40 liters a week for cars and vans while almost doubling the allocation for motor bikes to 14 liters in May 2023.
Registered taxi three-wheelers currently receive 22 liters, while other three-wheelers receive 14 liters per week.
Buses and lorries receive 125 liters and land vehicles get 45 liters.

Sri Lanka imposed weekly fuel quotas after the island’s economists printed money to suppress interest rates and triggered the worst currency crisis in the history of its central bank. (Colombo/July20/2023)
